questions.question: How did the Roman system of two consuls with mutual veto power prevent tyranny?
options: Consuls reported directly to the Senate who supervised their decisions always
The Senate and tribunes had to approve all major consular decisions
Consuls rotated military command every month to share authority equally
Consuls were required to consult the assembly before taking any action
Either consul could block the other's decisions, preventing one from accumulating power
questions.text_reference: Section 1: The Consulate - Shared Executive Power

questions.question: What was the relationship between tribunes and traditional magistrates? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Tribunes were subordinate to magistrates and had to obey their orders
Tribunes and magistrates shared equal authority in all governmental matters
Magistrates could not veto tribunes, but tribunes could veto magistrates
Tribunes answered directly to the plebeians, not to magistrates
Tribunes shared command of armies equally with consuls
The relationship was asymmetrical—designed to protect plebeian interests from magistratic abuse
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Tribune vs. Traditional Magistracies

questions.question: Why was the one-year term limit on the consulship a crucial check on power?
options: It prevented consuls from becoming too wealthy and accumulating personal fortune
It allowed younger men to hold office more quickly in their careers
Consuls could be held accountable for their actions after leaving office through prosecution
It guaranteed that different patrician families took turns holding the office
It prevented consuls from building loyalty among the soldiers under their command
It forced consuls to work together rather than compete for long-term power
questions.text_reference: Section 1: The One-Year Term and Accountability

questions.question: How did the organization of the Comitia Centuriata serve as a check on pure democracy? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Only patricians were allowed to participate in voting on major decisions
Citizens voted twice—once in assemblies and once in the Senate
Organized by wealth with wealthy centuries voting first and deciding early
Each tribe had exactly one vote regardless of population or property
The assembly was structured to advantage wealthy property owners
Voting was secret to prevent wealthy citizens from intimidating poorer voters
questions.text_reference: Section 1: Assemblies - Popular Participation, Aristocratic Advantage

questions.question: What does 'mixed constitution' mean in the context of the early Roman Republic?
options: Citizens from different tribes and regions governed together as a unified body
Magistrates provided executive energy; Senate provided stability; assemblies represented citizens—each checked others
Both patricians and plebeians were given exactly equal voting rights and power
The king shared governmental power with elected magistrates and the Senate
The constitution combined written law with unwritten custom and precedent
Multiple types of government institutions worked together with built-in power limitations

questions.question: How did the requirement that magistrates operate within written law serve as a check?
options: It prevented them from going to war against neighboring nations entirely
It reduced their salaries and made the positions less attractive
Magistrates had to follow legal procedures and could be prosecuted for violations
It gave the Senate complete control over all their governmental decisions
It made magistrates subservient to the assemblies and popular opinion

questions.question: Why could the threat of plebeian military secession force actual political change?
options: Plebeians outnumbered patricians in the Senate and could vote to change laws
Rome depended on plebeian soldiers for defense; without them government was paralyzed
Plebeians controlled the priesthoods and could deny religious authority to patricians
The assembly voted to support plebeian demands whenever they requested it
Patricians feared violent rebellion if they refused plebeian demands
Foreign enemies would invade if Rome had no army to defend it

questions.question: What was unusual about the tribune office compared to traditional magistracies?
options: Tribunes had more total power than consuls and controlled the government
Tribunes were chosen by the Senate instead of being elected by people
Created specifically for plebeians, stood outside traditional hierarchy, answered to plebeians directly
Tribunes could only serve one year while other magistrates served multiple years
Tribunes were the only magistrates with veto power over other officials
Tribunes were inviolable and could not be prosecuted for their actions
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Tribune vs. Traditional Magistracies

questions.question: How did the hierarchy of magistracies serve as a check on concentrated power? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Higher magistrates could veto all decisions made by lower magistrates
Each office had specific responsibilities; rotation prevented long-term power accumulation
Lower magistrates were appointed by higher magistrates rather than elected
Only patricians could hold higher offices while plebeians held lower offices
The cursus honorum required officials to hold multiple offices over time
Power was distributed among different officials rather than concentrated in one

questions.question: Why did Roman leaders accept the risk of deadlock between two consuls?
options: Deadlocks between consuls never actually happened in the Republican system
The Senate could always break any deadlock between the consuls immediately
Consuls were required to agree on all major decisions before implementation
The people could vote to override consular deadlock if necessary
One consul always deferred to the other's judgment in practice
They believed risk of deadlock was preferable to unchecked power enabling tyranny
